Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Canonical metrics, complex Monge-Ampere equations and geometric flows
Award.AbstractNarration: Abstract<br/><br/>Award: DMS-0847524<br/>Principal Investigator: Jian Song<br/><br/>The proposal focuses on a number of projects on canonical metrics<br/>and stability, geometric flows and complex Monge-Ampere<br/>equations. Such problems are fundamental in complex analysis and<br/>complex geometry, in tight relation to partial differential<br/>equations, algebraic geometry and mathematical physics. The<br/>recent progress and influx of new ideas from Ricci flow,<br/>pluripotential theory and the minimal model program in algebraic<br/>geometry have unravelled a deep, rich and unifying structure.<br/>The PI will investigate the limiting behavior of the Kahler-Ricci<br/>flow and its connection to the classification theory for<br/>algebraic varieties, inspired by Perelman's breakthrough in<br/>Hamilton's program to resolve the geometrization conjecture by<br/>Ricci flow. In particular, the PI aims to study the relation<br/>between the formation of finite time singularities of the<br/>Kahler-Ricci flow and the algebraic surgery in the minimal model<br/>program in algebraic geometry. The PI also intends to continue<br/>his study on canonical metrics of Einstein type on algebraic<br/>varieties and understand the analytic and geometric aspects of<br/>the singularities of such special metrics. The PI also plans to<br/>study the uniform approximation problem of the Monge-Ampere<br/>geodesics in infinite dimensional symmetric space by those in the<br/>finite dimensional Bergman spaces. The precise understanding of<br/>this problem will give new insight into Yau's conjecture on the<br/>relation between Kahler-Einstein metrics and certain stability in<br/>the sense of geometric invariant theory. The outcome of the<br/>proposed research will develop new tools and give profound<br/>insights and understanding of geometry and the structure of the<br/>universe.<br/><br/>Problems in the proposal arise naturally from our attempts to<br/>understand nonlinear differential equations from geometry and<br/>physics. The solutions to these problems will have strong impact<br/>on other fields of sciences such as physics and cosmology in the<br/>deep understanding of our universe. The method of analyzing<br/>singularities of nonlinear equations will have wide applications<br/>in physics, engineering and economics. Furthermore, the PI plans<br/>to disseminate the exciting research at the interface of geometry<br/>and analysis to a broad audience through lectures and<br/>workshops. The proposed project will bring in research and<br/>teaching innovation in mathematics from various disciplines and<br/>have an immediate beneficial effect on undergraduate and graduate<br/>students at Rutgers as well as in the regional mathematical<br/>community. The PI will also organize and participate in the<br/>integrated research/education programs and activities that will<br/>promote the education level of the nation.<br/>
